hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
Urban exploration or just drinking underground?
Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Still breathing, yes. Quiet nights are rare lately.
Spent some time fixing a typewriter last week. Old habit.
Hard to focus with all the sirens outside.
Machines don't file reports when things get loud.
Still here, for now. The city's louder than usual these days.
I restore typewriters, you know. Keeps my hands steady.
Been tricky lately, after the protests started again.
It's not illegal, just... less encouraged now.
Old keys give nothing away, at least.
Count myself lucky. Typewriter work helps pass the hours.
Most evenings I clean and restore old machines, Adlers mostly.
Last night the marches outside rattled my window—even the keys felt jumpy.
Tried to journal, but settled for oiling the carriage instead.
Funny, how these relics give you quiet in the chaos.
I suppose every hobby finds its purpose lately.
Just barely, with the city shifting underneath us.
Restoring old typewriters keeps me grounded, especially now.
I spend hours with ribbons and keys, making the old things sing again.
Yesterday, while the crowds roared, I wrote by lamplight—couldn't risk the network.
Noise seeps in, but there's privacy in ink and steel.
It’s a small rebellion, putting words somewhere they can’t scan.
I miss the days when it was just nostalgia, not necessity.
Still breathing, and counting each page I can finish.
My real comfort's with typewriters—restoring, typing, even the smell of oiled metal.
Decades ago, it was a quiet hobby. Now it’s almost a secret act.
With the BCI chaos and marches, you hear things through thin walls.
Three nights past, I typed a journal page while crowds chanted 'Simulation' outside.
Each stroke felt like hiding a memory, outsmarting a scanner, just for a moment.
Sometimes I think machines keep our secrets better than people ever could.
Strange, how these small acts feel bigger since Halden’s death and the files leaked.
hobby_answer: Still tuning, yes. Keeps the hands steady, mostly.
Parts are harder to find now. Too much attention lately.
Crowds on the street make it noisy, hard to focus.
Typewriters aren't flagged, but people ask questions.
I keep things quiet. No surprises.
Yes, tuning. Mechanical work needs a quiet mind.
With the protests, vibrations in the walls ruin alignment.
Replacement ribbons harder after last week's lockdown.
Funny thing, neighbors suddenly notice the sound more now.
I avoid open windows when cleaning these days.
Risky, but habits outlast systems.
Still at it, yes—old machines, old comforts.
Protests made the apartment shake, lost a few tiny screws.
Heard Council patrol scanning for unauthorized tech repairs nearby.
Sticking to paper lately. Safer than any terminal now.
Refused a repair job for a neighbor's device; too many watchers.
Harder to get supplies, but worth it.
The right click of a key, still calms the nerves.
Of course. Haven't found a better way to keep steady hands yet.
Last week, sirens outside—jarred a spring right out of the carriage.
The leaks made people suspicious; even an old Adler seems subversive now.
Used to share tools with neighbors, now everyone keeps to themselves.
Patrols circle, ask why I bother with these relics.
Paper, ink, moving parts—reminds me of quieter times.
Sometimes I type, sometimes just listen for the sound.
Hobby's become a hiding place. City makes hobbies feel dangerous.
Still tuning, yes. Hands remember what the city has forgotten.
My father taught me repairs on a Royal when I was twelve.
With all these leaks, BCI flags any odd purchase—one wrong ribbon, and they notice.
Last night, a protest lock-in—typed by candlelight, patrols banging downstairs.
Someone sprayed 'History is written, not coded' on my door.
Once, I'd lend out machines for youth exams—now, too risky, even to help a friend.
Relevant parts can only be bartered, quietly. Official channels watch every gram of metal.
Typing itself—keystrokes echo louder with every march.
It's strange. A habit for clarity now reads as an act of dissent.
